Unbalanced Optimal Transport: A Unified Framework for Object Detection

Henri De Plaen1* ‚ÄÉPierre-Fran√ßois De Plaen2* ‚ÄÉJohan A. K. Suykens1 ‚ÄÉMarc Proesmans2
Tinne Tuytelaars2 ‚ÄÉLuc Van Gool2,3
1ESAT-STADIUS, KU Leuven, Belgium ‚ÄÉ2ESAT-PSI, KU Leuven, Belgium
3Computer Vision Lab, ETH Z√ºrich, Switzerland
Abstract

During training, supervised object detection tries to correctly match the predicted bounding boxes and associated classification scores to the ground truth. This is essential to determine which predictions are to be pushed towards which solutions, or to be discarded. Popular matching strategies include matching to the closest ground truth box (mostly used in combination with anchors), or matching via the Hungarian algorithm (mostly used in anchor-free methods). Each of these strategies comes with its own properties, underlying losses, and heuristics. We show how Unbalanced Optimal Transport unifies these different approaches and opens a whole continuum of methods in between. This allows for a finer selection of the desired properties. Experimentally, we show that training an object detection model with Unbalanced Optimal Transport is able to reach the state-of-the-art both in terms of Average Precision and Average Recall as well as to provide a faster initial convergence. The approach is well suited for GPU implementation, which proves to be an advantage for large-scale models.

{NoHyper}**footnotetext: These authors contributed equally.

1 Introduction

Object detection models are in essence multi-task models, having to both localize objects in an image and classify them. In the context of supervised learning, each of these tasks heavily depends on a matching strategy. Indeed, determining which predicted object matches which ground truth object is a non-trivial yet essential task during the training (Figure¬†1(a)). In particular, the matching strategy must ensure that there is ideally exactly one prediction per ground truth object, at least during inference. Various strategies have emerged, often relying on hand-crafted components. They are proposed as scattered approaches that seem to have nothing in common, at least at first glance.

1.1 A Unifying Framework

To perform any match, a matching cost has to be determined. The example at Fig.¬†1(b) uses the Generalized Intersection over Union (GIoUGIoU\mathrm{GIoU})¬†[giou]. Given such a cost matrix, matching strategies include:

  • ‚Ä¢

    Matching each prediction to the closest ground truth object. This often requires that the cost lies under a certain threshold¬†[liu2016ssd, ren2015fasterrcnn, redmon2016yolo, lin2017focalloss], to avoid matching predictions that may be totally irrelevant for the current image. The disadvantage of this strategy is its redundancy: many predictions may point towards the same ground truth object. In Fig.¬†1(c), both predictions 1 and 4 are matched towards ground truth object A. Furthermore, some ground truth objects may be unmatched. A solution to this is to increase the number of predicted boxes drastically. This is typically the case with anchors boxes and region proposal methods.

  • ‚Ä¢

    The opposite strategy is to match each ground truth object to the best prediction¬†[he2015spatial, liu2016ssd]. This ensures that there is no redundancy and every ground truth object is matched. This also comes with the opposite problem: multiple ground truth objects may be matched to the same prediction. In Fig.¬†1(e), both ground truth objects A and B are matched to prediction 4. This can be mitigated by having more predictions, but then many of those are left unmatched, slowing convergence¬†[liu2016ssd].

  • ‚Ä¢

    A compromise is to perform a Bipartite Matching (BM), using the Hungarian algorithm¬†[kuhn1955hungarian, munkres1957algorithmstransportationhungarian], for example¬†[carion2020detr, zhu2020deformabledetr]. The matching is one-to-one, minimizing the total cost (Definition¬†2). Every ground truth object is matched to a unique prediction, thus reducing the number of predictions needed, as shown in Fig.¬†1(d). A downside is that the one-to-one matches may vary from one epoch to the next, again slowing down convergence¬†[li2022dndetr]. This strategy is difficult to parallelize, i.e. to take advantage of GPU architectures.

All of these strategies have different properties and it seems that one must choose either one or the other, optionally combining them using savant heuristics¬†[liu2016ssd]. There is a need for a unifying framework. As we show in this paper, Unbalanced Optimal Transport[chizat2018unbalanced] offers a good candidate for this (Figure¬†1). It not only unifies the different strategies here above, but also allows to explore all cases in between. The cases presented in Figures¬†1(c), 1(d) and 1(e) correspond to the limit cases. This opens the door for all intermediate settings. Furthermore, we show how regularizing the problem induces smoother matches, leading to faster convergence of DETR, avoiding the problem described for the BM. In addition, the particular choice of entropic regularization leads to a class of fast parallelizable algorithms on GPU known as scaling algorithms¬†[cuturi2013sinkhorn, chizat2018scaling], of which we provide a compiled implementation on GPU. Our code and additional resources are publicly available111https://hdeplaen.github.io/uotod.

1.2 Related Work

Matching Strategies‚ÄÉ Most two-stage models often rely on a huge number of initial predictions, which is then progressively reduced in the region proposal stage and refined in the classification stage. Many different strategies have been proposed for the initial propositions and subsequent reductions, ranging from training no deep learning networks¬†[girshick2014rcnn], to only train those for the propositions¬†[girshick2015fast, lin2017feature, he2015spatial], to training networks for both propositions and reductions¬†[ren2015fasterrcnn, pang2019libra, he2017maskrcnn, cai2018cascade, dai2016r]. Whenever a deep learning network is trained, each prediction is matched to the closest ground truth object provided it lies beneath a certain threshold. Moreover, the final performance of these models heavily depends on the hand-crafted anchors [liu2020objectdetectionsurvey].

Many one-stage models rely again on predicting a large number of initial predictions or anchor boxes, covering the entire image. As before, each anchor box is matched towards the closest ground truth object with certain threshold constraints¬†[redmon2016yolo, lin2017focalloss]. In¬†[liu2016ssd], this is combined with matching each ground truth object to the closest anchor box and a specific ratio heuristic between the matched and unmatched predictions. The matching of the fixed anchors is justified to avoid a collapse of the predictions towards the same ground truth objects. Additionally, this only works if the number of initial predictions is sufficiently large to ensure that every ground truth object is matched by at least one prediction. Therefore, it requires further heuristics, such as Non-Maximal Suppression (NMS) to guarantee a unique prediction per ground truth object, at least during the inference.

By using the Hungarian algorithm, DETR [carion2020detr] removed the need for a high number of initial predictions. The matched predictions are improved with a multi-task loss, and the remaining predictions are trained to predict the background class ‚àÖ\varnothing. Yet, the model converges slowly due to the instability of BM, causing inconsistent optimization goals at early training stages [li2022dndetr]. Moreover, the sequential nature of the Hungarian algorithm does not take full advantage of the GPU architecture. Several subsequent works accelerate the convergence of DETR by improving the architecture of the model [zhu2020deformabledetr, liu2021dabdetr] and by adding auxiliary losses [li2022dndetr], but not by exploring the matching procedure.

Optimal Transport‚ÄÉ The theory of Optimal Transport (OT) emerges from an old problem¬†[monge1781memoire], relaxed by a newer formulation¬†[kantorovich]. It gained interest in the machine learning community since the re-discovery of Sinkhorn‚Äôs algorithm¬†[cuturi2013sinkhorn] and opened the door for improvements in a wide variety of applications ranging from graphical models¬†[montavon2016wasserstein], kernel methods¬†[kolouri2016sliced, de2020wasserstein], loss design¬†[frogner2015learningwasserstein], auto-encoders¬†[tolstikhin2017wasserstein, kolouri2018sliced, rubenstein2018latent] or generative adversarial networks¬†[arjovsky2017wasserstein, gulrajani2017improved].

More recent incursions in computer vision have been attempted, e.g. for the matching of predicted classes¬†[Han_2020_CVPR_Workshops], a loss for rotated object boxes¬†[pmlr-v139-yang21l] or a new metric for performance evaluation¬†[otani2022optimal]. Considering the matching of predictions to ground truth objects, recent attempts using OT bare promising results¬†[ge2021ota, ge2021yolox]. However, when the Hungarian algorithm is mentioned, it is systematically presented in opposition to OT¬†[ge2021ota, vo2022review]. We lay a rigorous connection between those two approaches in computer vision.

Unbalanced OT has seen a much more recent theoretical development¬†[chizat2018unbalanced, chizat-these]. The hard mass conservation constraints in the objective function are replaced by soft penalization terms. Its applications are scarcer, but we must mention here relatively recent machine learning applications in motion tracking¬†[9152115] and domain adaptation¬†[fatras2021unbalanced].

1.3 Contributions

  1. 1.

    We propose a unifying matching framework based on Unbalanced Optimal Transport. It encompasses both the Hungarian algorithm, the matching of the predictions to the closest ground truth boxes and the ground truth boxes to the closest predictions;

  2. 2.

    We show that these three strategies correspond to particular limit cases and we subsequently present a much broader class of strategies with varying properties;

  3. 3.

    We demonstrate how entropic regularization can speed up the convergence during training and additionally take advantage of GPU architectures;

  4. 4.

    We justify the relevancy of our framework by exploring its interaction with NMS and illustrate how it is on par with the state-of-the-art.

2 Optimal Transport

In this section, we show how Optimal Transport and then its Unbalanced extension unify both the Hungarian algorithm used in DETR¬†[carion2020detr], and matching each prediction to the closest ground truth object used in both Faster R-CNN¬†[ren2015fasterrcnn] and SSD¬†[liu2016ssd]. We furthermore stress the advantages of entropic regularization, both computationally and qualitatively. This allows us to explore a new continuum of matching methods, with varying properties.

Definition 1 (Optimal Transport).

Given a distribution ùõÇ‚ààŒîNpùõÇsuperscriptŒîsubscriptùëÅùëù\bm{\alpha}\in\Delta^{N_{p}} associated to the predictions {ùê≤^i}i=1Npsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript^ùê≤ùëñùëñ1subscriptùëÅùëù\{\hat{\bm{y}}_{i}\}_{i=1}^{N_{p}}, and another distribution ùõÉ‚ààŒîNgùõÉsuperscriptŒîsubscriptùëÅùëî\bm{\beta}\in\Delta^{N_{g}} associated with the ground truth objects {ùê≤j}j=1Ngsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptùê≤ùëóùëó1subscriptùëÅùëî\{\bm{y}_{j}\}_{j=1}^{N_{g}}. Let us consider a pair-wise matching cost ‚Ñímatch‚Äã(ùê≤^i,ùê≤j)subscript‚Ñímatchsubscript^ùê≤ùëñsubscriptùê≤ùëó\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\bm{y}_{j}) between a prediction ùê≤^isubscript^ùê≤ùëñ\hat{\bm{y}}_{i} and a ground truth object ùê≤jsubscriptùê≤ùëó\bm{y}_{j}. We now define Optimal Transport (OT) as finding the match ùêèùêè\bm{P} that minimizes the following problem:

ùë∑^=arg‚Äãminùë∑‚ààùí∞‚Äã(ùú∂,ùú∑)‚Äã{‚àëi,j=1Np,NgPi,j‚Äã‚Ñímatch‚Äã(ùíö^i,ùíöj)},^ùë∑ùë∑ùí∞ùú∂ùú∑argminsuperscriptsubscriptùëñùëó1subscriptùëÅùëùsubscriptùëÅùëîsubscriptùëÉùëñùëósubscript‚Ñímatchsubscript^ùíöùëñsubscriptùíöùëó\hat{\bm{P}}=\underset{\bm{P}\,\in\,\mathcal{U}(\bm{\alpha},\bm{\beta})}{\mathrm{arg\,min}}\left\{\sum_{i,j=1}^{N_{p},N_{g}}P_{i,j}\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}\left(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\bm{y}_{j}\right)\right\}, (1)

with transport polytope (admissible solutions) ùí∞‚Äã(ùõÇ,ùõÉ)={ùêè‚àà‚Ñù‚â•0Np√óNg:‚àëj=1NgPi,j=Œ±i,‚àëi=1NpPi,j=Œ≤j}.ùí∞ùõÇùõÉconditional-setùêèsuperscriptsubscript‚Ñùabsent0subscriptùëÅùëùsubscriptùëÅùëîformulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptùëó1subscriptùëÅùëîsubscriptùëÉùëñùëósubscriptùõºùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1subscriptùëÅùëùsubscriptùëÉùëñùëósubscriptùõΩùëó\mathcal{U}(\bm{\alpha},\bm{\beta})=\left\{\bm{P}\in\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}^{N_{p}\times N_{g}}:\sum_{j=1}^{N_{g}}P_{i,j}=\alpha_{i},\sum_{i=1}^{N_{p}}P_{i,j}=\beta_{j}\right\}.

Provided that certain conditions apply to the underlying cost ‚Ñímatchsubscript‚Ñímatch\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}, the minimum defines a distance between ùú∂ùú∂\bm{\alpha} and ùú∑ùú∑\bm{\beta}, referred to as the Wasserstein distance ùí≤‚Äã(ùú∂,ùú∑)ùí≤ùú∂ùú∑\mathcal{W}(\bm{\alpha},\bm{\beta}) (for more information, we refer to monographs¬†[villani2009optimal, santambrogio, peyre2019computational]; see also Appendix¬†A.2).

2.1 The Hungarian Algorithm

The Hungarian algorithm solves the Bipartite Matching (BM). We will now show how this is a particular case of Optimal Transport.

Definition 2 (Bipartite Matching).

Given the same objects as in Definition¬†¬†1, the Bipartite Matching (BM) minimizes the cost of the pairwise matches between the ground truth objects with the predictions:

œÉ^=argmin{‚àëj=1Ng‚Ñímatch(ùíö^œÉ‚Äã(j),ùíöj):œÉ‚ààùí´Ng(‚ü¶Np‚üß)},\hat{\sigma}=\mathrm{arg\,min}\left\{\sum_{j=1}^{N_{g}}\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}\left(\hat{\bm{y}}_{\sigma(j)},\bm{y}_{j}\right):\sigma\in\mathcal{P}_{N_{g}}(\llbracket N_{p}\rrbracket)\right\}, (2)

where ùí´Ng(‚ü¶Np‚üß)={œÉ‚ààùí´(‚ü¶Np‚üß)||œÉ|=Ng}\mathcal{P}_{N_{g}}(\llbracket N_{p}\rrbracket)=\left.\big{\{}\sigma\in\mathcal{P}(\llbracket N_{p}\rrbracket)\,\right||\sigma|=N_{g}\big{\}} is the set of possible combinations of NgsubscriptùëÅùëîN_{g} in NpsubscriptùëÅùëùN_{p}, with ùí´(‚ü¶Np‚üß)\mathcal{P}(\llbracket N_{p}\rrbracket) the power set of ‚ü¶Np‚üßdelimited-‚ü¶‚üßsubscriptùëÅùëù\llbracket N_{p}\rrbracket (the set of all subsets).

BM tries to assign each ground truth ùíöjsubscriptùíöùëó\bm{y}_{j} to a different prediction ùíö^isubscript^ùíöùëñ\hat{\bm{y}}_{i} in a way to minimize the total cost. In contrast to OT, BM does not consider any underlying distributions ùú∂ùú∂\bm{\alpha} and ùú∑ùú∑\bm{\beta}, all ground truth objects and predictions are implicitly considered to be of same mass. Furthermore, it only allows one ground truth to be matched to a unique prediction, some of these predictions being left aside and matched to nothing (which is then treated as a matching to the background ‚àÖ\varnothing). The OT must match all ground truth objects to all predictions, not allowing any predictions to be left aside. However, the masses of the ground truth objects are allowed to be split between different predictions and inversely, as long as their masses correctly sum up (ùë∑‚ààùí∞‚Äã(ùú∂,ùú∑)ùë∑ùí∞ùú∂ùú∑\bm{P}\in\mathcal{U}(\bm{\alpha},\bm{\beta})).

Particular Case of OT‚ÄÉ A solution for an imbalanced number of predictions compared to the number of ground truth objects would be to add dummy ground truth objects‚Äîthe background ‚àÖ\varnothing‚Äîto even the balance. Concretely, one could add a new ground truth ùíöNg+1=‚àÖsubscriptùíösubscriptùëÅùëî1\bm{y}_{N_{g}+1}=\varnothing, with the mass equal to the unmatched number of predictions. In fact, doing so directly results in performing a BM.

Solving the Problem‚ÄÉ Both OT and BM are linear programs. Using generic formulations would lead to a (Np+Ng+1)√óNp‚Äã(Ng+1)subscriptùëÅùëùsubscriptùëÅùëî1subscriptùëÅùëùsubscriptùëÅùëî1\left(N_{p}+N_{g}+1\right)\times N_{p}\left(N_{g}+1\right) equality constraint matrix. It is thus better to exploit the particular bipartite structure of the problem. In particular, two families of algorithms have emerged: Dual Ascent Methods and Auction Algorithms¬†[peyre2019computational]. The Hungarian algorithm is a particular case of the former and classically runs with an ùí™‚Äã(Np4)ùí™superscriptsubscriptùëÅùëù4\mathcal{O}\left(N_{p}^{4}\right) complexity¬†[munkres1957algorithmstransportationhungarian], further reduced to cubic by¬†[hungarian-cubic]. Although multiple GPU implementations of a BM solver have been proposed¬†[gpu-bipartite, gpu-hungarian, gpu-matching], the problem remains poorly parallelizable because of its sequential nature. To allow for efficient parallelization, we must consider a slightly amended problem.

2.2 Regularization

We show here how we can replace the Hungarian algorithm by a class of algorithms well-suited for parallelization, obtained by adding an entropy regularization.

Definition 3 (OT with regularization).

We consider a regularization parameter œµ‚àà‚Ñù‚â•0italic-œµsubscript‚Ñùabsent0\epsilon\in\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}. Extending Definition¬†1 (OT), we define the Optimal Transport with regularization as the following minimization problem:

ùë∑^=arg‚Äãminùë∑‚ààùí∞‚Äã(ùú∂,ùú∑)‚Äã{‚àëi,j=1Np,NgPi,j‚Äã‚Ñímatch‚Äã(ùíö^i,ùíöj)‚àíœµ‚ÄãH‚Äã(ùë∑)},^ùë∑ùë∑ùí∞ùú∂ùú∑argminsuperscriptsubscriptùëñùëó1subscriptùëÅùëùsubscriptùëÅùëîsubscriptùëÉùëñùëósubscript‚Ñímatchsubscript^ùíöùëñsubscriptùíöùëóitalic-œµHùë∑\hat{\bm{P}}=\underset{\bm{P}\,\in\,\mathcal{U}(\bm{\alpha},\bm{\beta})}{\mathrm{arg\,min}}\left\{\sum_{i,j=1}^{N_{p},N_{g}}P_{i,j}\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}\left(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\bm{y}_{j}\right)-\epsilon\,\mathrm{H}(\bm{P})\right\}, (5)

with H:ŒîN√óM‚Üí‚Ñù‚â•0:ùêè‚Ü¶‚àí‚àëi,jPi,j‚Äã(log‚Å°(Pi,j)‚àí1):H‚ÜísuperscriptŒîùëÅùëÄsubscript‚Ñùabsent0:maps-toùêèsubscriptùëñùëósubscriptùëÉùëñùëósubscriptùëÉùëñùëó1\mathrm{H}:\Delta^{N\times M}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}:\bm{P}\mapsto-\sum_{i,j}P_{i,j}(\log(P_{i,j})-1) the entropy of the match ùêèùêè\bm{P}, with 0‚Äãln‚Å°(0)=00000\ln(0)=0 by definition.

Sinkhorn‚Äôs Algorithm‚ÄÉ The entropic regularization used when finding the match ùë∑^^ùë∑\hat{\bm{P}} ensures that the problem is smooth for œµ‚â†0italic-œµ0\epsilon\neq 0 (see Figure¬†3). The advantage is that it can now be solved very efficiently using scaling algorithms and in this particular case the algorithm of Sinkhorn. It is particularly suited for parallelization¬†[cuturi2013sinkhorn], with some later speed refinements¬†[greenkorn, screenkorn]. Reducing the regularization progressively renders the scaling algorithms numerically unstable, although some approaches have been proposed to reduce the regularization further by working in log-space¬†[schmitzer2019stabilized, chizat2018scaling]. In the limit of œµ‚Üí0‚Üíitalic-œµ0\epsilon\rightarrow 0, we recover the exact OT (Definition¬†1) and the scaling algorithms cannot be used anymore. Parallelization is lost and we must resolve to use the sequential algorithms developed in Section¬†1. In brief, regularization allows to exploit GPU architectures efficiently, whereas the Hungarian algorithm and similar cannot.

Smoother Matches‚ÄÉ When no regularization is used as in the Hungarian algorithm, close predictions and ground truth objects can exchange their matches from one epoch to the other, during the training. This causes a slow convergence of DETR in the early stages of the training¬†[li2022dndetr]. The advantage of the regularization not only lies in the existence of efficient algorithms but also allows for a reduction of sparsity. This results in a less drastic match than the Hungarian algorithm obtains. A single ground truth could be matched to multiple predictions and inversely. The proportion of these multiple matches is controlled by the regularization parameter œµitalic-œµ\epsilon. An illustration can be found in Figures¬†2(a) and 2(b).

2.3 Unbalanced Optimal Transport

We will now show how considering soft constraints instead of hard leads to an even greater generalization of the various matching techniques used in object detection models. In particular, matching each prediction to the closest ground truth is a limit case of the Unbalanced OT.

Definition 4 (Unbalanced OT).

We consider two constraint parameters œÑ1,œÑ2‚àà‚Ñù‚â•0subscriptùúè1subscriptùúè2subscript‚Ñùabsent0\tau_{1},\tau_{2}\in\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}. Extending Definition¬†3 (OT with regularization), we define the Unbalanced OT with regularization¬†[chizat2018scaling] as the following minimization problem:

ùë∑^=arg‚Äãminùë∑‚àà‚Ñù‚â•0Np√óNg{œµKL(ùë∑‚à•ùë≤œµ)+\displaystyle\hat{\bm{P}}=\underset{\bm{P}\in\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}^{N_{p}\times N_{g}}}{\mathrm{arg\,min}}\biggl{\{}\epsilon\,\mathrm{KL}(\bm{P}\,\|\,\bm{K}_{\epsilon})\,+ œÑ1‚ÄãKL‚Äã(ùë∑‚ÄãùüèNg‚à•ùú∂)subscriptùúè1KLconditionalùë∑subscript1subscriptùëÅùëîùú∂\displaystyle\,\tau_{1}\mathrm{KL}(\bm{P}\bm{1}_{N_{g}}\,\|\,\bm{\alpha}) (6)
+\displaystyle+ œÑ2KL(ùüèNp‚ä§ùë∑‚à•ùú∑)},\displaystyle\,\tau_{2}\mathrm{KL}(\bm{1}_{N_{p}}^{\top}\bm{P}\,\|\,\bm{\beta})\biggr{\}},

where KL:‚Ñù‚â•0N√óM√ó‚Ñù>0N√óM‚Üí‚Ñù‚â•0:(ùêî,ùêï)‚Ü¶‚àëi,j=1N√óMUi,j‚Äãlog‚Å°(Ui,j/Vi,j)‚àíUi,j+Vi,j:KL‚Üísubscriptsuperscript‚ÑùùëÅùëÄabsent0subscriptsuperscript‚ÑùùëÅùëÄabsent0superscriptsubscript‚Ñùabsent0absent:maps-toùêîùêïsuperscriptsubscriptùëñùëó1ùëÅùëÄsubscriptùëàùëñùëósubscriptùëàùëñùëósubscriptùëâùëñùëósubscriptùëàùëñùëósubscriptùëâùëñùëó\mathrm{KL}:\mathbb{R}^{N\times M}_{\geq 0}\times\mathbb{R}^{N\times M}_{>0}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}^{\phantom{N}}:(\bm{U},\bm{V})\mapsto\sum_{i,j=1}^{N\times M}U_{i,j}\log(U_{i,j}/V_{i,j})-U_{i,j}+V_{i,j} is the Kullback-Leibler divergence ‚Äì also called relative entropy ‚Äì between matrices or vectors when M=1ùëÄ1M=1, with 0‚Äãln‚Å°(0)=00000\ln(0)=0 by definition. The Gibbs kernel ùêäœµsubscriptùêäitalic-œµ\bm{K}_{\epsilon} is given by (Kœµ)i,j=exp‚Å°(‚àí‚Ñímatch‚Äã(ùê≤^i,ùê≤j)/œµ)subscriptsubscriptùêæitalic-œµùëñùëósubscript‚Ñímatchsubscript^ùê≤ùëñsubscriptùê≤ùëóitalic-œµ\left(K_{\epsilon}\right)_{i,j}=\exp\left(-\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}\left(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\bm{y}_{j}\right)/\epsilon\right).

We can see by development that the first term corresponds to the matching term ùë∑‚Äã‚Ñímatchùë∑subscript‚Ñímatch\bm{P}\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}} and an extension of the entropic regularization term H‚Äã(ùë∑)Hùë∑\mathrm{H}(\bm{P}). The two additional terms replace the transport polytope‚Äôs hard constraints ùí∞‚Äã(ùú∂,ùú∑)ùí∞ùú∂ùú∑\mathcal{U}(\bm{\alpha},\bm{\beta}) that required an exact equality of mass for both marginals. These new soft constraints allow for a more subtle sensitivity to the mass constraints as it allows to slightly diverge from them. It is clear that in the limit of œÑ1,œÑ2‚Üí+‚àû‚Üísubscriptùúè1subscriptùúè2\tau_{1},\tau_{2}\rightarrow+\infty, we recover the ‚Äúbalanced‚Äù problem (Definition¬†3). This definition naturally also defines Unbalanced OT without regularization if œµ=0italic-œµ0\epsilon=0. The matching term would remain and the entropic one disappear.

Matching to the Closest‚ÄÉ Another limit case is however particularly interesting in the quest for a unifying framework of the matching strategies. If the mass constraint is to be perfectly respected for the predictions (œÑ1‚Üí‚àû‚Üísubscriptùúè1\tau_{1}\rightarrow\infty), but not at all for the ground truth objects (œÑ2=0subscriptùúè20\tau_{2}=0), it suffices to assign the closest ground truth to each prediction. The same ground truth object could be assigned to multiple predictions and another could not be matched at all, not respecting the hard constraint for the ground truth ùú∑ùú∑\bm{\beta}. Each prediction however is exactly assigned once, perfectly respecting the mass constraint for the predictions ùú∂ùú∂\bm{\alpha}. By assigning a low enough value to the background, a prediction would be assigned to it provided all the other ground truth objects are further. In other words, the background cost would play the role of a threshold value.

Proposition 2 (Matching to the closest).

We consider the same objects as Proposition¬†1. In the limit of œÑ1‚Üí‚àû‚Üísubscriptùúè1\tau_{1}\rightarrow\infty and œÑ2=0subscriptùúè20\tau_{2}=0, Unbalanced OT (Definition¬†4) without regularization (œµ=0italic-œµ0\epsilon=0) admits as solution each prediction being matched to the closest ground truth object unless that distance is greater than a threshold value ‚Ñímatch‚Äã(ùê≤^i,ùê≤Ng+1=‚àÖ)=c‚àÖsubscript‚Ñímatchsubscript^ùê≤ùëñsubscriptùê≤subscriptùëÅùëî1subscriptùëê\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}\left(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\bm{y}_{N_{g}+1}=\varnothing\right)=c_{\varnothing}. It is then matched to the background ‚àÖ\varnothing. In particular, we have

(7)
Proof.

We refer to Appendix¬†B.2. ‚àé

The converse also holds. If the ground truth objects mass constraints were to be perfectly respected (œÑ2‚Üí‚àû‚Üísubscriptùúè2\tau_{2}\rightarrow\infty), but not the predictions (œÑ1‚Üí0‚Üísubscriptùúè10\tau_{1}\rightarrow 0), each ground truth would then be matched to the closest prediction. The background would be matched to the remaining predictions. Some predictions could not be matched and other ones multiple times. The limits of Unbalanced OT are illustrated in Fig.¬†4. By setting the threshold sufficiently high, we get an exact minimum, i.e., where every prediction is matched to the closest ground truth. This can be observed in Figure¬†2(d).

Scaling Algorithm‚ÄÉ Similarly as before, adding entropic regularization (œµ‚â†0italic-œµ0\epsilon\neq 0) to the Unbalanced OT allows it to be solved efficiently on GPU with a scaling algorithm, as an extension of Sinkhorn‚Äôs algorithm¬†[chizat2018scaling, chizat-these]. The regularization still also allows for smoother matches, as shown in Figure¬†2(c).

Softmax‚ÄÉ In the limit of œÑ1‚Üí+‚àû‚Üísubscriptùúè1\tau_{1}\rightarrow+\infty and œÑ2=0subscriptùúè20\tau_{2}=0, the solution corresponds to a softmax over the ground truth objects for each prediction. The regularization ŒµùúÄ\varepsilon controls then the ‚Äúsoftness‚Äù of the softmax, with Œµ=1ùúÄ1\varepsilon=1 corresponding to the conventional softmax and Œµ‚Üí0‚ÜíùúÄ0\varepsilon\rightarrow 0 the matching to the closest. We refer to Appendix¬†C.2 for more information.

3 Matching

Following previous work¬†[carion2020detr, zhu2020deformabledetr, ren2015fasterrcnn, redmon2016yolo, liu2016ssd], we define a multi-task matching cost between a prediction ùíö^isubscript^ùíöùëñ\hat{\bm{y}}_{i} and a ground truth object ùíöjsubscriptùíöùëó\bm{y}_{j} as the composition of a classification loss ensuring that similar object classes are matched together and a localization loss ensuring the correspondence of the positions and shapes of the matched boxes ‚Ñí‚Äã(ùíö^i,ùíöj)=‚Ñíclassification‚Äã(ùíÑ^i,ùíÑj)+‚Ñílocalization‚Äã(ùíÉ^i,ùíÉj)‚Ñísubscript^ùíöùëñsubscriptùíöùëósubscript‚Ñíclassificationsubscript^ùíÑùëñsubscriptùíÑùëósubscript‚Ñílocalizationsubscript^ùíÉùëñsubscriptùíÉùëó\mathcal{L}(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\bm{y}_{j})=\mathcal{L}_{\text{classification}}(\hat{\bm{c}}_{i},\bm{c}_{j})+\mathcal{L}_{\text{localization}}(\hat{\bm{b}}_{i},\bm{b}_{j}). Most models, however, do not use the same loss to determine the matches as the one used to train the model. We therefore refer to these two losses as ‚Ñímatchsubscript‚Ñímatch\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}} and ‚Ñítrainsubscript‚Ñítrain\mathcal{L}_{\text{train}}. The training procedure is the following: first find a match ùë∑^^ùë∑\hat{\bm{P}} given a matching strategy and matching cost ‚Ñímatchsubscript‚Ñímatch\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}, then compute the loss Np‚Äã‚àëi=1Np‚àëj=1NgP^i‚Äãj‚Äã‚Ñítrain‚Äã(ùíö^i,ùíöj)subscriptùëÅùëùsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1subscriptùëÅùëùsuperscriptsubscriptùëó1subscriptùëÅùëîsubscript^ùëÉùëñùëósubscript‚Ñítrainsubscript^ùíöùëñsubscriptùíöùëóN_{p}\sum_{i=1}^{N_{p}}\sum_{j=1}^{N_{g}}\hat{P}_{ij}\mathcal{L}_{\text{train}}(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\bm{y}_{j}) where the particular training loss for the background ground truth includes only a classification term ‚Ñítrain‚Äã(ùíö^i,‚àÖ)=‚Ñíclassification‚Äã(ùíÑ^i,‚àÖ)subscript‚Ñítrainsubscript^ùíöùëñsubscript‚Ñíclassificationsubscript^ùíÑùëñ\mathcal{L}_{\text{train}}(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\varnothing)=\mathcal{L}_{\text{classification}}(\hat{\bm{c}}_{i},\varnothing).

3.1 Detection Transformer (DETR)

The object detection is performed by matching the predictions to the ground truth boxes with the Hungarian algorithm applied to the loss ‚Ñímatch‚Äã(ùíö^i,ùíöj)=Œªprob‚Äã(1‚àí‚ü®ùíÑ^i,ùíÑj‚ü©)+Œª‚Ñì1‚Äã‚à•ùíÉ^i‚àíùíÉj‚à•1+ŒªGIoU‚Äã(1‚àíGIoU‚Äã(ùíÉ^i,ùíÉj))subscript‚Ñímatchsubscript^ùíöùëñsubscriptùíöùëósubscriptùúÜprob1subscript^ùíÑùëñsubscriptùíÑùëósubscriptùúÜsuperscript‚Ñì1subscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscript^ùíÉùëñsubscriptùíÉùëó1subscriptùúÜGIoU1GIoUsubscript^ùíÉùëñsubscriptùíÉùëó\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\bm{y}_{j})=\lambda_{\text{prob}}(1-\left<\hat{\bm{c}}_{i},\bm{c}_{j}\right>)+\lambda_{\ell^{1}}\lVert\hat{\bm{b}}_{i}-\bm{b}_{j}\rVert_{1}+\lambda_{\mathrm{GIoU}}(1-\mathrm{GIoU}(\hat{\bm{b}}_{i},\bm{b}_{j})) (Definition¬†2). To do so, the number of predictions and ground truth boxes must be of the same size. This is achieved by padding the ground truths with (Np‚àíNg)subscriptùëÅùëùsubscriptùëÅùëî(N_{p}-N_{g}) dummy background ‚àÖ\varnothing objects. Essentially, this is the same as what is developed in Proposition¬†1. The obtained match is then used to define an object-specific loss, where each matched prediction is pushed toward its corresponding ground truth object. The predictions that are not matched to a ground truth object are considered to be matched with the background and are pushed to predict the background class. The training loss uses the cross-entropy (CECE\mathrm{CE}) for classification: ‚Ñítrain‚Äã(ùíö^i,ùíöj)=ŒªCE‚Äã‚ÑíCE‚Äã(ùíÑ^i,ùíÑj)+Œª‚Ñì1‚Äã‚à•ùíÉ^i‚àíùíÉj‚à•1+ŒªGIoU‚Äã(1‚àíGIoU‚Äã(ùíÉ^i,ùíÉj))subscript‚Ñítrainsubscript^ùíöùëñsubscriptùíöùëósubscriptùúÜCEsubscript‚ÑíCEsubscript^ùíÑùëñsubscriptùíÑùëósubscriptùúÜsuperscript‚Ñì1subscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscript^ùíÉùëñsubscriptùíÉùëó1subscriptùúÜGIoU1GIoUsubscript^ùíÉùëñsubscriptùíÉùëó\mathcal{L}_{\text{train}}(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\bm{y}_{j})=\lambda_{\mathrm{CE}}\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{CE}}(\hat{\bm{c}}_{i},\bm{c}_{j})+\lambda_{\ell^{1}}\lVert\hat{\bm{b}}_{i}-\bm{b}_{j}\rVert_{1}+\lambda_{\mathrm{GIoU}}(1-\mathrm{GIoU}(\hat{\bm{b}}_{i},\bm{b}_{j})). By directly applying Proposition¬†1 and adding entropic regularization (Definition¬†3), we can use Sinkhorn‚Äôs algorithm and push each prediction ùíö^isubscript^ùíöùëñ\hat{\bm{y}}_{i} to ground truth ùíöjsubscriptùíöùëó\bm{y}_{j} according to weight P^i,jsubscript^ùëÉùëñùëó\hat{P}_{i,j}. In particular, for any non-zero P^i,Ng+1‚â†0subscript^ùëÉùëñsubscriptùëÅùëî10\hat{P}_{i,N_{g}+1}\neq 0, the prediction ùíö^isubscript^ùíöùëñ\hat{\bm{y}}_{i} is pushed toward the background ùíöNg+1=‚àÖsubscriptùíösubscriptùëÅùëî1\bm{y}_{N_{g}+1}=\varnothing with weight P^i,Ng+1subscript^ùëÉùëñsubscriptùëÅùëî1\hat{P}_{i,N_{g}+1}.

3.2 Single Shot MultiBox Detector (SSD)

The Single Shot MultiBox Detector¬†[liu2016ssd] uses a matching cost only comprised of the IoUIoU\mathrm{IoU} between the fixed anchor boxes ùíÉ~isubscript~ùíÉùëñ\tilde{\bm{b}}_{i} and the ground truth boxes: ‚Ñímatch‚Äã(ùíö^i,ùíöj)=1‚àíIoU‚Äã(ùíÉ~i,ùíÉj)subscript‚Ñímatchsubscript^ùíöùëñsubscriptùíöùëó1IoUsubscript~ùíÉùëñsubscriptùíÉùëó\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\bm{y}_{j})=1-\mathrm{IoU}(\tilde{\bm{b}}_{i},\bm{b}_{j}) (the GIoUGIoU\mathrm{GIoU} was not published yet¬†[giou]). Each ground truth is first matched toward the closest anchor box. Anchor boxes are then matched to a ground truth object if the matching cost is below a threshold of 0.5. In our framework, this corresponds to applying œÑ1=0subscriptùúè10\tau_{1}=0 and œÑ2‚Üí‚àû‚Üísubscriptùúè2\tau_{2}\to\infty for the first phase and then œÑ1‚Üí‚àû‚Üísubscriptùúè1\tau_{1}\to\infty and œÑ2=0subscriptùúè20\tau_{2}=0 with c‚àÖ=0.5subscriptùëê0.5c_{\varnothing}=0.5 (see Proposition¬†2). Here again, by adding entropic regularization (Definition¬†4), we can solve this using a scaling algorithm. We furthermore can play with the parameters œÑ1subscriptùúè1\tau_{1} and œÑ2subscriptùúè2\tau_{2} to make the matching tend slightly more towards a matching done with the Hungarian algorithm (Figure¬†2). Again, the training uses a different loss than the matching, in particular ‚Ñítrain‚Äã(ùíö^i,ùíöj)=ŒªCE‚Äã‚ÑíCE‚Äã(ùíÑ^i,ùíÑj)+Œªsmooth¬†‚Äã‚Ñì1‚Äã‚Ñísmooth¬†‚Äã‚Ñì1‚Äã(ùíÉ^i,ùíÉj)subscript‚Ñítrainsubscript^ùíöùëñsubscriptùíöùëósubscriptùúÜCEsubscript‚ÑíCEsubscript^ùíÑùëñsubscriptùíÑùëósubscriptùúÜsmooth¬†superscript‚Ñì1subscript‚Ñísmooth¬†superscript‚Ñì1subscript^ùíÉùëñsubscriptùíÉùëó\mathcal{L}_{\text{train}}(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\bm{y}_{j})=\lambda_{\mathrm{CE}}\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{CE}}(\hat{\bm{c}}_{i},\bm{c}_{j})+\lambda_{\text{smooth }\ell^{1}}\mathcal{L}_{\text{smooth }\ell^{1}}(\hat{\bm{b}}_{i},\bm{b}_{j}).

Hard Negative Mining‚ÄÉ Instead of using all negative examples Nneg=(Np‚àíNg)subscriptùëÅnegsubscriptùëÅùëùsubscriptùëÅùëîN_{\text{neg}}=(N_{p}-N_{g}) (predictions matched to background), the method sorts them using the highest confidence loss ‚ÑíCE‚Äã(ùíÑ^i,‚àÖ)subscript‚ÑíCEsubscript^ùíÑùëñ\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{CE}}(\hat{\bm{c}}_{i},\varnothing) and picks the top ones so that the ratio between the hard negatives and positives Npos=NgsubscriptùëÅpossubscriptùëÅùëîN_{\text{pos}}=N_{g} is at most 3 to 1. Since ùë∑^^ùë∑\hat{\bm{P}} is non-binary, we define the number of negatives and positives to be the sum of the matches to the background Nneg=Np‚Äã‚àëi=1NpP^i,(Ng+1)subscriptùëÅnegsubscriptùëÅùëùsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1subscriptùëÅùëùsubscript^ùëÉùëñsubscriptùëÅùëî1N_{\text{neg}}=N_{p}\sum_{i=1}^{N_{p}}\hat{P}_{i,(N_{g}+1)} and to the ground truth objects Npos=Np‚Äã‚àëj=1Ng‚àëi=1NpP^i‚ÄãjsubscriptùëÅpossubscriptùëÅùëùsuperscriptsubscriptùëó1subscriptùëÅùëîsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1subscriptùëÅùëùsubscript^ùëÉùëñùëóN_{\text{pos}}=N_{p}\sum_{j=1}^{N_{g}}\sum_{i=1}^{N_{p}}\hat{P}_{ij}. 4 Experimental Results & Discussion

We show that matching based on Unbalanced Optimal Transport generalizes many different matching strategies and performs on par with methods that use either Bipartite Matching or anchor boxes along with matching each prediction to the closest ground truth box with a threshold. We then analyze the influence of constraint parameter œÑ2subscriptùúè2\tau_{2} by training SSD with and without NMS for multiple parameter values. Finally, we show that OT with entropic regularization both improves the convergence and is faster to compute than the Hungarian algorithm in case of many matches.

4.1 Setup

Datasets‚ÄÉ We perform experiments on a synthetic object detection dataset with 4.800 training and 960 validation images and on the large-scale COCO [lin2014microsoft] dataset with 118,287 training and 5,000 validation test images. We report on mean Average Precision (AP) and mean Average Recall (AR). The two metrics are an average of the per-class metrics following COCO‚Äôs official evaluation procedure. For the Color Boxes synthetic dataset, we uniformly randomly draw between 0 and 30 rectangles of 20 different colors from each image. Appendix I provides the detailed generation procedure and sample images.

Training‚ÄÉ For a fair comparison, the classification and localization costs for matching and training are identical to the ones used by the models. Unless stated otherwise, we train the models with their default hyper-parameter sets. DETR and Deformable DETR are trained with hyper-parameters Œªprob=ŒªCE=2subscriptùúÜprobsubscriptùúÜCE2\lambda_{\text{prob}}=\lambda_{\mathrm{CE}}=2, Œª‚Ñì1=5subscriptùúÜsuperscript‚Ñì15\lambda_{\ell^{1}}=5 and ŒªGIoU=2subscriptùúÜGIoU2\lambda_{\mathrm{GIoU}}=2. For Deformable DETR, we found the classification cost to be overwhelmed by the localization costs in the regularized minimization problem (Definition 3). We therefore set Œªprob=5subscriptùúÜprob5\lambda_{\text{prob}}=5. We, however keep ŒªCE=2subscriptùúÜCE2\lambda_{\mathrm{CE}}=2 so that the final loss value for a given matching remains unchanged. SSD is trained with original hyper-parameters ŒªCE=Œªsmooth¬†‚Äã‚Ñì1=1subscriptùúÜCEsubscriptùúÜsmooth¬†superscript‚Ñì11\lambda_{\mathrm{CE}}=\lambda_{\text{smooth }\ell^{1}}=1. For OT, we set the entropic regularization to œµ=œµ0/(log‚Å°(2‚ÄãNp)+1)italic-œµsubscriptitalic-œµ02subscriptùëÅùëù1\epsilon=\epsilon_{0}/(\log{(2N_{p})}+1) where œµ0=0.12subscriptitalic-œµ00.12\epsilon_{0}=0.12 for all models (App.¬†D). In the following experiments, the Unbalanced OT is solved with multiple values of œÑ2subscriptùúè2\tau_{2} whereas œÑ1subscriptùúè1\tau_{1} is fixed to a large value œÑ1=100subscriptùúè1100\tau_{1}=100 to simulate a hard constraint. In practice, we limit the number of iterations of the scaling algorithm. This provides a good enough approximation¬†[ge2021yolox].

4.2 Unified Matching Strategy

DETR and Deformable DETR‚ÄÉ Convergence curves for DETR on the Color Boxes dataset are shown in Fig.¬†5 and associated metrics are presented in Table¬†1. DETR converges in half the number of epochs with the regularized balanced OT formulation. This confirms that one reason for slow DETR convergence is the discrete nature of BM, which is unstable, especially in the early stages of training. Training the model for more epochs with either BM or OT does not improve metrics as the model starts to overfit. Appendix E provides qualitative examples and a more detailed convergence analysis. We evaluate how these results translate to faster converging DETR-like models by additionally training Deformable DETR¬†[zhu2020deformabledetr]. In addition to model improvements, Deformable DETR makes three times more predictions than DETR and uses a sigmoid focal loss¬†[lin2017focalloss] instead of a softmax cross-entropy loss for both classification costs. Table¬†1 gives results on Color Boxes and COCO. We observe that the entropy term does not lead to faster convergence. Indeed, Deformable DETR converges in 505050 epochs with both matching strategies. Nevertheless, both OT and bipartite matching lead to similar AP and AR.

SSD and the Constraint Parameter‚ÄÉ To better understand how unbalanced OT bridges the gap between DETR‚Äôs and SSD‚Äôs matching strategies, we analyze the variation in performance of SSD for different values of œÑ2subscriptùúè2\tau_{2}. Results for an initial learning rate of 0.0005 are displayed in Table 2. In the second row, the parameter value is close to zero. From Proposition 2 and when œµ‚Üí0‚Üíitalic-œµ0\epsilon\to 0, each prediction is matched to the closest ground truth box unless the matching cost exceeds 0.5. Thus, multiple predictions are matched to each ground truth box, and NMS is needed to eliminate near duplicates. When NMS is removed, AP drops by 25.8 points and AR increases by 10.2 points. We observe similar results for the original SSD matching strategy (1st row), which suggests matching each ground truth box to the closest anchor box does not play a huge role in the two-stage matching procedure from SSD. The lower part of Table 1 shows the same for COCO. When œÑ2‚Üí+‚àû‚Üísubscriptùúè2\tau_{2}\to+\infty, one recovers the balanced formulation used in DETR (last row). Removing NMS leads to a 2.9 points drop for AP and a 9.7 points increase for AR. Depending on the field of application, it may be preferable to apply a matching strategy with a low œÑ2subscriptùúè2\tau_{2} and with NMS when precision is more important or without NMS when the recall is more important. Moreover, varying parameter œÑ2subscriptùúè2\tau_{2} offers more control on the matching strategy and therefore on the precision-recall trade-off [buckland1994precisionrecall].

Computation Time‚ÄÉ For a relatively small number of predictions, implementations of Sinkhorn perform on par with the Hungarian algorithm¬†(Fig. 6). The ‚Äúbalanced‚Äù algorithm is on average 2.6ms slower than the Hungarian algorithm for 100100100 predictions (DETR) and 1.5ms faster for 300 predictions (Deformable DETR). For more predictions, GPU parallelization of the Sinkhorn algorithm makes a large difference (more than 50x speedup). As a reference point, SSD300 and SSD512 make 8,73287328,732 and 24,5642456424,564 predictions.

5 Conclusion and Future Work

Throughout the paper, we showed both theoretically and experimentally how Unbalanced Optimal Transport unifies the Hungarian algorithm, matching each ground truth object to the best prediction and each prediction to the best ground truth, with or without threshold.

Experimentally, using OT and Unbalanced OT with entropic regularization is on par with the state-of-the-art for DETR, Deformable DETR and SSD. Moreover, we showed that entropic regularization lets DETR converge faster on the Color Boxes dataset and that parameter œÑ2subscriptùúè2\tau_{2} offers better control of the precision-recall trade-off. Finally, we showed that the scaling algorithms compute large numbers of matches faster than the Hungarian algorithm.

Limitations and Future Work‚ÄÉ The convergence improvement of the regularized OT formulation compared to bipartite matching seems to hold only for DETR and on small-scale datasets. Further investigations may include Wasserstein-based matching costs for a further unification of the theory and the reduction of the entropy with time, as it seems to boost convergence only in early phases, but not in fine-tuning.

Unbalanced Optimal Transport: A Unified Framework for Object Detection
Supplementary Material

Appendix A Optimal Transport Discussion

The Otpimal Transport formulation presented throughout the paper is formulated in discrete space. In this section, we present the more general formulation of which the discrete one is a particular case of. We also discuss the Wasserstein distance in the particular context of object detection and the effect of regularization on the uniqueness of the solutions. Only the case of the original OT formulation‚Äîor ‚Äúbalanced‚Äù case‚Äîis covered here.

A.1 Continuous Formulation

More generally, we define Optimal Transport in its continuous form.

Definition 5 (Continuous Optimal Transport).

Given two distributions Œ±‚ààùí´+‚Äã(X)ùõºsubscriptùí´ùëã\alpha\in\mathscr{P}_{+}(X) and Œ≤‚ààùí´+‚Äã(Y)ùõΩsubscriptùí´ùëå\beta\in\mathscr{P}_{+}(Y) of same mass ‚à´Œ±‚Äãdx=‚à´Œ≤‚Äãdyùõºdifferential-dùë•ùõΩdifferential-dùë¶\int\alpha\,\mathrm{d}x=\int\beta\,\mathrm{d}y, and given an underlying cost function c:X√óY‚Üí[0,+‚àû]:ùëê‚Üíùëãùëå0c:X\times Y\rightarrow[0,+\infty], we define Continuous Optimal Transport as the minimization of a transport cost

inf{‚à´X√óYc‚ÄãdŒ≥:Œ≥‚ààU‚Äã(Œ±,Œ≤)},infimumconditional-setsubscriptùëãùëåùëêdifferential-dùõæùõæùëàùõºùõΩ\inf\left\{\int_{X\times Y}c\,\mathrm{d}\gamma:\gamma\in U(\alpha,\beta)\right\}, (8)

with admissible solutions, here called transport plans

U‚Äã(Œ±,Œ≤)={Œ≥‚ààùí´+‚Äã(X√óY):‚à´YdŒ≥=Œ±and‚à´XdŒ≥=Œ≤}.ùëàùõºùõΩconditional-setùõæsubscriptùí´ùëãùëåformulae-sequencesubscriptùëådifferential-dùõæùõºandsubscriptùëãdifferential-dùõæùõΩU(\alpha,\beta)=\bigg{\{}\gamma\in\mathscr{P}_{+}(X\times Y):\int_{Y}\mathrm{d}\gamma=\alpha\quad\text{and}\quad\int_{X}\mathrm{d}\gamma=\beta\bigg{\}}. (9)

If a minimum exists, it is called the optimal transport plan Œ≥^^ùõæ\hat{\gamma}.

We replace the probability simplex ŒîNsuperscriptŒîùëÅ\Delta^{N} by the space on probability distributions ùí´+‚Äã(X)subscriptùí´ùëã\mathscr{P}_{+}(X) on XùëãX. The transport plans are the set of joint probability distribution Œ≥‚ààùí´+‚Äã(X√óY)ùõæsubscriptùí´ùëãùëå\gamma\in\mathscr{P}_{+}(X\times Y), whose marginal distributions are Œ±ùõº\alpha and Œ≤ùõΩ\beta. The discrete formulation (Definition¬†1) is a particular case where Œ±=‚àëiŒ±i‚ÄãŒ¥ùíö^iùõºsubscriptùëñsubscriptùõºùëñsubscriptùõøsubscript^ùíöùëñ\alpha=\sum_{i}\alpha_{i}\delta_{\hat{\bm{y}}_{i}}, Œ≤=‚àëjŒ≤j‚ÄãŒ¥ùíöjùõΩsubscriptùëósubscriptùõΩùëósubscriptùõøsubscriptùíöùëó\beta=\sum_{j}\beta_{j}\delta_{\bm{y}_{j}} and the cost c=‚Ñímatchùëêsubscript‚Ñímatchc=\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}. In this case, a minimum always exists.

A.2 Wasserstein Distance

This infimum defines a distance between Œ±ùõº\alpha and Œ≤ùõΩ\beta, called the Wasserstein distance ùí≤p‚Äã(Œ±,Œ≤)subscriptùí≤ùëùùõºùõΩ\mathcal{W}_{p}(\alpha,\beta), provided that the underlying cost function is also a distance c=dpùëêsuperscriptùëëùëùc=d^{p} up to some exponent p‚àà[1,+‚àû[p\in[1,+\infty[. In our case, ‚Ñímatchsubscript‚Ñímatch\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}} is not a distance. More formally, sum of distances are distances. The ‚Ñì1superscript‚Ñì1\ell^{1} norm is a distance, and 1‚àíIoU1IoU1-\mathrm{IoU}, or 1‚àíGIoU1GIoU1-\mathrm{GIoU} also are¬†[giou]. However, the cross entropy or the focal loss do not satisfy the triangular inequality or the symmetry properties. In consequence, we cannot talk about a Wasserstein distance here.

Furthermore, interpreting a Wasserstein distance ùí≤p‚Äã(Œ±,Œ≤)subscriptùí≤ùëùùõºùõΩ\mathcal{W}_{p}(\alpha,\beta) would not make much sense even if the underlying matching cost was to be a distance. Indeed, the distributions Œ±ùõº\alpha and Œ≤ùõΩ\beta would be the same at every iteration in our framework. In other words, the distance would always be computed between the same points, but the underlying cost would change and it would be different for each image. Each iteration would be computing the distance of two same points in a changing geometry and each image would have its own evolving geometry.

For completeness, we must mention that the regularized version does not define a distance as ùí≤p,reg.‚Äã(ùú∂,ùú∂)=‚àíœµ‚ÄãH‚Äã(ùë∞Np,Np/Np)>0subscriptùí≤ùëùreg.ùú∂ùú∂italic-œµHsubscriptùë∞subscriptùëÅùëùsubscriptùëÅùëùsubscriptùëÅùëù0\mathcal{W}_{p,\text{reg.}}(\bm{\alpha},\bm{\alpha})=-\epsilon\,\mathrm{H}(\bm{I}_{N_{p},N_{p}}/N_{p})>0 with ùë∞Np,Npsubscriptùë∞subscriptùëÅùëùsubscriptùëÅùëù\bm{I}_{N_{p},N_{p}} the identity matrix of size NpsubscriptùëÅùëùN_{p} (we refer to¬†[genevay, genevay-these, sinkhorn-divergences] for a broader discussion on the subject).

A.3 Uniqueness

We consider here the discrete formulation used throughout the paper. By classical linear programming theory, the non-regularized problem admits a non-unique solution if and only if multiple extreme points minimize the problem. In that case, the set of minimizers is all the linear interpolations between those extreme points. The regularization term however is œµitalic-œµ\epsilon-strongly convex; the regularized problem thus always has a unique solution¬†[peyre2019computational].

Appendix B Proofs of the Propositions

In this section, we provide the proofs of Propositions¬†1 and 2 and enrich them with some insight through a few additional results.

B.1 Hungarian Algorithm

Before providing a proof of the particular equivalence between OT and BM, we first consider a more general result.

Lemma 1.

We consider the rational probability simplex Œî‚ÑöN={ùêÆ‚àà‚Ñö‚â•0N|‚àëiui=1}superscriptsubscriptŒî‚ÑöùëÅconditional-setùêÆsubscriptsuperscript‚ÑöùëÅabsent0subscriptùëñsubscriptùë¢ùëñ1\Delta_{\mathbb{Q}}^{N}=\{\bm{u}\in\mathbb{Q}^{N}_{\geq 0}|\sum_{i}u_{i}=1\}. where the common measure is the greatest rational such that all non-zero elements of both distributions are multiples of it:

The common measure extends the GCDGCD\mathrm{GCD} to non-integers. As an example CM‚Äã([2/3,4/5])=2/15CM2345215\mathrm{CM}(\left[\,\nicefrac{{2}}{{3}},\,\nicefrac{{4}}{{5}}\,\right])=\nicefrac{{2}}{{15}} and CM‚Äã([2/3,5/6,4/7])=1/42CM235647142\mathrm{CM}(\left[\,\nicefrac{{2}}{{3}},\,\nicefrac{{5}}{{6}},\,\nicefrac{{4}}{{7}}\,\right])=\nicefrac{{1}}{{42}}.

Proof.

In¬†[brualdi_2006], Corollary 8.1.3, an algorithm is given to build the exhaustive list of extreme points. It comprises only minimum and subtraction operations, which leave the common measure unchanged. ‚àé

Corollary 1.

Given the underlying distributions as in Proposition¬†1, the extreme points of ùí∞‚Äã(ùõÇ,ùõÉ)ùí∞ùõÇùõÉ\,\mathcal{U}(\bm{\alpha},\bm{\beta}) are comprised only of zeros and 1/Np1subscriptùëÅùëù1/N_{p}:

(12)

This is a direct consequence of Lemma¬†1 and the mass constraints directly implying that Pi‚â§1/NpsubscriptùëÉùëñ1subscriptùëÅùëùP_{i}\leq 1/N_{p} for all iùëñi. In this particular case, there is also an equivalence.

Lemma 2.

Given the underlying distributions as in Proposition¬†1, the extreme points of ùí∞‚Äã(ùõÇ,ùõÉ)ùí∞ùõÇùõÉ\,\mathcal{U}(\bm{\alpha},\bm{\beta}) are comprised only of zeros and 1/Np1subscriptùëÅùëù1/N_{p}:

ùë∑¬†is an extreme point of¬†ùí∞‚Äã(ùú∂,ùú∑)‚ü∫ùë∑‚àà{0,1/Np}Np√ó(Ng+1)andùë∑‚ààùí∞‚Äã(ùú∂,ùú∑).formulae-sequenceùë∑¬†is an extreme point of¬†ùí∞(ùú∂,ùú∑)‚ü∫ùë∑superscript01subscriptùëÅùëùsubscriptùëÅùëùsubscriptùëÅùëî1andùë∑ùí∞ùú∂ùú∑\text{$\bm{P}$ is an extreme point of $\,\mathcal{U}(\bm{\alpha},\bm{\beta})$}\qquad\Longleftrightarrow\qquad\bm{P}\in\left\{0,1/N_{p}\right\}^{N_{p}\times\left(N_{g}+1\right)}\quad\text{and}\quad\bm{P}\in\,\mathcal{U}(\bm{\alpha},\bm{\beta}). (13)
Proof.

We consider Corollary¬†1 and add the fact that such a match ùë∑‚àà{0,1/Np}Np√ó(Ng+1)ùë∑superscript01subscriptùëÅùëùsubscriptùëÅùëùsubscriptùëÅùëî1\bm{P}\in\left\{0,1/N_{p}\right\}^{N_{p}\times\left(N_{g}+1\right)} only has one element per row (or prediction if we prefer) to satisfy the mass constraints. Therefore, it cannot be any interpolation of two other extreme points. ‚àé

We however also give a more direct proof, based essentially on the same arguments.

Proof.

We will first show that the elements of the match ùë∑ùë∑\bm{P} corresponding to any extreme point, can only be 1/Np1subscriptùëÅùëù1/N_{p} or 00. Therefore we can consider the associated bipartite graph of the problem: each prediction consists in a node iùëñi and each ground truth a node jùëój. Each non-zero value entry of ùë∑ùë∑\bm{P} connects nodes iùëñi and jùëój with weight Pi,jsubscriptùëÉùëñùëóP_{i,j}. The solution is admissible if and only if the weight of each node iùëñi equals Œ±isubscriptùõºùëñ\alpha_{i} and jùëój equals Œ≤jsubscriptùõΩùëó\beta_{j}. A transport plan ùë∑ùë∑\bm{P} is an extreme point if and only if the corresponding bipartite graph only consists in trees, or equivalently, it has no cycle (Theorem 8.1.2 of¬†[brualdi_2006]).

Because the mass constraint must all sum up to one for the predictions, we already know that Pi,j‚â§1/NpsubscriptùëÉùëñùëó1subscriptùëÅùëùP_{i,j}\leq 1/N_{p}. We will now proceed ad absurdum and suppose that there were to be an entry 0<Pi,j<1/Np0subscriptùëÉùëñùëó1subscriptùëÅùëù0<P_{i,j}<1/N_{p} connecting a prediction and a ground truth. In order to satisfy the mass constraints, they would both also have to be connected to another prediction and another ground truth. Similarly, these would also have to be connected to at least one prediction and one ground truth, and so on. They would all form a same graph, or be ‚Äúlinked‚Äù together in other words. By consequence, each new connection must be done to yet ‚Äúunlinked‚Äù prediction and ground truth to avoid the formation of a cycle. Considering that there are NpsubscriptùëÅùëùN_{p} predictions, there would be at the end at least 2‚ÄãNp2subscriptùëÅùëù2N_{p} edges within the graph. This is incompatible with the fact that there cannot be any cycle (Corollary 8.1.3 of¬†[brualdi_2006]). By consequence, the entries of ùë∑ùë∑\bm{P} must be either 00 or 1/Np1subscriptùëÅùëù1/N_{p}. ‚àé

We can now proceed to prove the said proposition.

provided the background cost is constant: ‚Ñímatch‚Äã(ùê≤^i,‚àÖ)=c‚àÖsubscript‚Ñímatchsubscript^ùê≤ùëñsubscriptùëê\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}\left(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\varnothing\right)=c_{\varnothing}. B.2 Minimum Matching with Threshold

Proposition 2 (Matching to the closest).

We consider the same objects as Proposition¬†1. In the limit of œÑ1‚Üí‚àû‚Üísubscriptùúè1\tau_{1}\rightarrow\infty and œÑ2=0subscriptùúè20\tau_{2}=0, Unbalanced OT (Definition¬†4) without regularization (œµ=0italic-œµ0\epsilon=0) admits as solution each prediction being matched to the closest ground truth object unless that distance is greater than a threshold value ‚Ñímatch‚Äã(ùê≤^i,ùê≤Ng+1=‚àÖ)=c‚àÖsubscript‚Ñímatchsubscript^ùê≤ùëñsubscriptùê≤subscriptùëÅùëî1subscriptùëê\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}\left(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\bm{y}_{N_{g}+1}=\varnothing\right)=c_{\varnothing}. It is then matched to the background ‚àÖ\varnothing. In particular, we have

P^i,j={1Npif¬†‚Äãj=arg‚Å°minj‚Å£‚àà‚Å£‚ü¶Ng+1‚üß‚Äã{‚Ñímatch‚Äã(ùíö^i,ùíöj)},0otherwise.subscript^ùëÉùëñùëócases1subscriptùëÅùëùif¬†ùëósubscriptminùëódelimited-‚ü¶‚üßsubscriptùëÅùëî1subscript‚Ñímatchsubscript^ùíöùëñsubscriptùíöùëó0otherwise\hat{P}_{i,j}=\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}\frac{1}{N_{p}}&\text{if }j=\mathrm{\arg\,min}_{j\in\llbracket N_{g}+1\rrbracket}\left\{\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}\left(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\bm{y}_{j}\right)\right\},\\ 0&\text{otherwise}.\end{array}\right. (16)
Proof.

By taking the limit of œÑ1‚Üí+‚àû‚Üísubscriptùúè1\tau_{1}\rightarrow+\infty and setting œµ,œÑ2=0italic-œµsubscriptùúè20\epsilon,\tau_{2}=0, the problem becomes

arg‚Äãmin{‚àëi,j=1Np,Ng+1Pi,j‚Äã‚Ñímatch‚Äã(ùíöi,ùíö^j)|ùë∑‚àà‚Ñù‚â•0Np√ó(Ng+1)},s.t.‚àëjPi,j=1/Np‚àÄi.argminconditional-setsuperscriptsubscriptùëñùëó1subscriptùëÅùëùsubscriptùëÅùëî1subscriptùëÉùëñùëósubscript‚Ñímatchsubscriptùíöùëñsubscript^ùíöùëóùë∑superscriptsubscript‚Ñùabsent0subscriptùëÅùëùsubscriptùëÅùëî1s.t.subscriptùëósubscriptùëÉùëñùëó1subscriptùëÅùëùfor-allùëñ\begin{array}[]{ll}\mathrm{arg\,min}&\left\{\left.\sum_{i,j=1}^{N_{p},N_{g}+1}P_{i,j}\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}\left(\bm{y}_{i},\hat{\bm{y}}_{j}\right)\right|\bm{P}\in\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}^{N_{p}\times\left(N_{g}+1\right)}\right\},\\ \text{s.t.}&\sum_{j}P_{i,j}=1/N_{p}\qquad\forall i.\end{array} (17)

We can now see that the choice made in each row is independent from the other rows. In other words, each ground truth object can be matched independently of the others. The minimization is then obtained if, for each prediction (or row), all the weight is put on the ground truth object with minimum cost, including the background. This leads to¬†Eq.¬†16. ‚àé

Corollary 2 (Matching to the closest without threshold).

Provided the background cost is more expensive than any other cost c‚àÖ>max{‚Ñímatch(ùê≤^i,ùê≤j)|i‚àà‚ü¶Np‚üßandj‚àà‚ü¶Ng‚üß}c_{\varnothing}>\max\left.\big{\{}\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}\left(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\bm{y}_{j}\right)\right|i\in\llbracket N_{p}\rrbracket\,\text{and}\,j\in\llbracket N_{g}\rrbracket\big{\}}, each prediction will always be matched to the closest ground truth.

In theory, this a much too strong condition, the background cost can just be greater than the minimum cost for each prediction ‚Ñímatch‚Äã(ùíö^i,‚àÖ)>minj‚Å°{‚Ñímatch‚Äã(ùíö^i,ùíöj)}subscript‚Ñímatchsubscript^ùíöùëñsubscriptùëósubscript‚Ñímatchsubscript^ùíöùëñsubscriptùíöùëó\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}\left(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\varnothing\right)>\min_{j}\left\{\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}\left(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\bm{y}_{j}\right)\right\}. In practice, however, this does not change much. It suffices to set the background cost high enough and we are assured to get a minimum. One could also imagine a different background cost for each prediction in order to have a more granular threshold.

Appendix C Scaling Algorithms

We present here the two scaling algorithms: Sinkhorn‚Äôs algorithm for ‚Äú‚Äòbalanced‚Äù Optimal Transport and its variant for Unbalanced Optimal Transport. We further show how it is connected to the softmax.

C.1 Sinkhorn and Variant

These two algorithms are taken from¬†[peyre2019computational, chizat2018scaling]. In particular we can see how taking œÑ1‚Üí+‚àû‚Üísubscriptùúè1\tau_{1}\rightarrow+\infty and œÑ2‚Üí+‚àû‚Üísubscriptùúè2\tau_{2}\rightarrow+\infty in Algorithm¬†2 leads to Algorithm¬†1. Indeed, we have limœÑ‚Üí+‚àûœÑœÑ+œµ=1subscript‚Üíùúèùúèùúèitalic-œµ1\lim_{\tau\rightarrow+\infty}\frac{\tau}{\tau+\epsilon}=1. By ‚äò‚äò\oslash, we denote the element-wise (or Hadamard) division.

C.2 Connection with the Softmax

In this section, we lay a connection between the softmax and the solutions of the scaling algorithms, in particular considering its first iterations. We consider more precisely the softmin, which is the opposite of the softmax: (softmin‚Äã(ùíó))i=(softmax‚Äã(‚àíùíó))i=exp‚Å°(‚àívi)/‚àëj=1Nexp‚Å°(‚àívj)subscriptsoftminùíóùëñsubscriptsoftmaxùíóùëñsubscriptùë£ùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùëó1ùëÅsubscriptùë£ùëó\left(\mathrm{softmin}(\bm{v})\right)_{i}=\left(\mathrm{softmax}(-\bm{v})\right)_{i}=\exp(-v_{i})/\sum_{j=1}^{N}\exp(-v_{j}), for any vector ùíó‚àà‚ÑùNùíósuperscript‚ÑùùëÅ\bm{v}\in\mathbb{R}^{N}. Considering a softmin over ‚Ñímatch‚Äã(ùíö^i,ùíöj)subscript‚Ñímatchsubscript^ùíöùëñsubscriptùíöùëó\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}\left(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\bm{y}_{j}\right) is thus the same as considering the softmax over ‚àí‚Ñímatch‚Äã(ùíö^i,ùíöj)subscript‚Ñímatchsubscript^ùíöùëñsubscriptùíöùëó-\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}\left(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\bm{y}_{j}\right), as in¬†[loftr]. By simplicity, we will only use the softmax terminology.

We first consider the case without background, where the underlying distributions are equal to ùú∂=ùüèNp/Npùú∂subscript1subscriptùëÅùëùsubscriptùëÅùëù\bm{\alpha}=\bm{1}_{N_{p}}/N_{p} and ùú∑=ùüèNg/Ngùú∑subscript1subscriptùëÅùëîsubscriptùëÅùëî\bm{\beta}=\bm{1}_{N_{g}}/N_{g}. This does not correspond to the setup of Prop.¬†1 and only approximates a one-to-one match if Np=NgsubscriptùëÅùëùsubscriptùëÅùëîN_{p}=N_{g}.

C.2.2 With Background

We now consider the underlying distributions as defined in Prop.¬†1. Fundamentally, adding a background with a different weight than the other ground truth objects does not change much. The unbalanced case with œÑ1‚Üí+‚àû‚Üísubscriptùúè1\tau_{1}\rightarrow+\infty and œÑ2=0subscriptùúè20\tau_{2}=0 remains exactly the same. The opposite case with œÑ1=0subscriptùúè10\tau_{1}=0 and œÑ2‚Üí+‚àû‚Üísubscriptùúè2\tau_{2}\rightarrow+\infty now becomes

P^i,j=1Np‚Äãexp‚Å°(‚àí‚Ñímatch‚Äã(ùíö^i,ùíöj))‚àëi=1Npexp‚Å°(‚àí‚Ñímatch‚Äã(ùíö^i,ùíöj)),subscript^ùëÉùëñùëó1subscriptùëÅùëùsubscript‚Ñímatchsubscript^ùíöùëñsubscriptùíöùëósuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1subscriptùëÅùëùsubscript‚Ñímatchsubscript^ùíöùëñsubscriptùíöùëó\hat{P}_{i,j}=\frac{1}{N_{p}}\frac{\exp\left(-\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}\left(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\bm{y}_{j}\right)\right)}{\sum_{i=1}^{N_{p}}\exp\left(-\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}\left(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\bm{y}_{j}\right)\right)}, (26)

for all 1‚â§j‚â§Ng1ùëósubscriptùëÅùëî1\leq j\leq N_{g}, and

P^i,j=Np‚àíNgNp‚Äãexp‚Å°(‚àí‚Ñímatch‚Äã(ùíö^i,ùíöj))‚àëi=1Npexp‚Å°(‚àí‚Ñímatch‚Äã(ùíö^i,ùíöj)),subscript^ùëÉùëñùëósubscriptùëÅùëùsubscriptùëÅùëîsubscriptùëÅùëùsubscript‚Ñímatchsubscript^ùíöùëñsubscriptùíöùëósuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1subscriptùëÅùëùsubscript‚Ñímatchsubscript^ùíöùëñsubscriptùíöùëó\hat{P}_{i,j}=\frac{N_{p}-N_{g}}{N_{p}}\frac{\exp\left(-\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}\left(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\bm{y}_{j}\right)\right)}{\sum_{i=1}^{N_{p}}\exp\left(-\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}\left(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\bm{y}_{j}\right)\right)}, (27)

for j=Ng+1ùëósubscriptùëÅùëî1j=N_{g}+1 (the background). In essence, this ensures that the mass constraints induced by œÑ2subscriptùúè2\tau_{2} are satisfied, as the background has a higher weight.

Similarly, the ‚Äúbalanced‚Äù case is the same as Eq.¬†21 for all 1‚â§j‚â§Ng1ùëósubscriptùëÅùëî1\leq j\leq N_{g}. For j=Ng+1ùëósubscriptùëÅùëî1j=N_{g}+1, we have the same with an added factor:

Pi,j=(Np‚àíNg)‚Äãexp‚Å°(‚àí‚Ñímatch‚Äã(ùíö^i,ùíöj))‚àëi=1Npexp‚Å°(‚àí‚Ñímatch‚Äã(ùíö^i,ùíöj))‚ãÖ‚àëj=1Ngexp‚Å°(‚àí‚Ñímatch‚Äã(ùíö^i,ùíöj)).subscriptùëÉùëñùëósubscriptùëÅùëùsubscriptùëÅùëîsubscript‚Ñímatchsubscript^ùíöùëñsubscriptùíöùëósuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1subscriptùëÅùëù‚ãÖsubscript‚Ñímatchsubscript^ùíöùëñsubscriptùíöùëósuperscriptsubscriptùëó1subscriptùëÅùëîsubscript‚Ñímatchsubscript^ùíöùëñsubscriptùíöùëóP_{i,j}=\left(N_{p}-N_{g}\right)\frac{\exp\left(-\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}\left(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\bm{y}_{j}\right)\right)}{\sum_{i=1}^{N_{p}}\exp\left(-\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}\left(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\bm{y}_{j}\right)\right)\cdot\sum_{j=1}^{N_{g}}\exp\left(-\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}\left(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\bm{y}_{j}\right)\right)}. (28)

C.2.3 Other Regularization

We can also consider other cases that having the regularization Œµ=1ùúÄ1\varepsilon=1. The regularization ŒµùúÄ\varepsilon controls the ‚Äúsoftness‚Äù of the softmax: the greater is ŒµùúÄ\varepsilon, the softer is the minimum; the smaller, the harder. In the case of no regularization at all (Œµ‚Üí0‚ÜíùúÄ0\varepsilon\rightarrow 0), the softmax is exactly a minimum as proven in Prop.¬†2. This can be observed at Fig.¬†8.

Appendix D Scaling the Entropic Parameter

In this section, we consider the particular choice of the entropic regularization parameter. In particular, we study how it scales with the problem size.

D.2 Entropy

The study of uniform matches is relevant as they have an easy formulation for their entropy.

Definition 8 (Entropy).

The entropy H:ŒîNp√ó(Ng+1)‚Üí‚Ñù‚â•0:H‚ÜísuperscriptŒîsubscriptùëÅùëùsubscriptùëÅùëî1subscript‚Ñùabsent0\mathrm{H}:\Delta^{N_{p}\times\left(N_{g}+1\right)}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0} of a match ùêèùêè\bm{P} is given by

H‚Äã(ùë∑)=def.‚àí‚àëi,jPi,j‚Äã(log‚Å°(Pi,j)‚àí1).superscriptdef.Hùë∑subscriptùëñùëósubscriptùëÉùëñùëósubscriptùëÉùëñùëó1\mathrm{H}(\bm{P})\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\text{def.}}}{{=}}-\sum_{i,j}P_{i,j}\left(\log\left(P_{i,j}\right)-1\right). (37)

If one of the elements would be zero, i.e., Pi,j=0subscriptùëÉùëñùëó0P_{i,j}=0, we consider Pi,j‚Äãlog‚Å°(Pi,j‚àí1)=0subscriptùëÉùëñùëósubscriptùëÉùëñùëó10P_{i,j}\log\left(P_{i,j}-1\right)=0.

The latter condition ensures that the entropy is well defined. This choice is justified as it remains consistent with the limit. Some authors prefer another convention¬†[peyre2019computational].

D.3 Rule of Thumb

We first consider two different matches of different dimensions ùë∑1‚ààŒîNp,1√ó(Ng,1+1)subscriptùë∑1superscriptŒîsubscriptùëÅùëù1subscriptùëÅùëî11\bm{P}_{1}\in\Delta^{N_{p,1}\times\left(N_{g,1}+1\right)} and ùë∑2‚ààŒîNp,2√ó(Ng,2+1)subscriptùë∑2superscriptŒîsubscriptùëÅùëù2subscriptùëÅùëî21\bm{P}_{2}\in\Delta^{N_{p,2}\times\left(N_{g,2}+1\right)}. In this case, the OT with regularization cost (Definition¬†3) is given by ‚àëi,j=1Np,(Ng+1)Pi,j‚Äã‚Ñímatch‚Äã(ùíö^i,ùíöj)‚àíœµ‚ÄãH‚Äã(ùë∑)superscriptsubscriptùëñùëó1subscriptùëÅùëùsubscriptùëÅùëî1subscriptùëÉùëñùëósubscript‚Ñímatchsubscript^ùíöùëñsubscriptùíöùëóitalic-œµHùë∑\sum_{i,j=1}^{N_{p},\left(N_{g}+1\right)}P_{i,j}\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}\left(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\bm{y}_{j}\right)-\epsilon\,\mathrm{H}(\bm{P}). The goal is to scale the regularization parameter œµitalic-œµ\epsilon in such a way that the weight of the entropy is proportionally the same. Because of unit mass of any match, we could assume that the first term ‚àëi,j=1Np,(Ng+1)Pi,j‚Äã‚Ñímatch‚Äã(ùíö^i,ùíöj)superscriptsubscriptùëñùëó1subscriptùëÅùëùsubscriptùëÅùëî1subscriptùëÉùëñùëósubscript‚Ñímatchsubscript^ùíöùëñsubscriptùíöùëó\sum_{i,j=1}^{N_{p},\left(N_{g}+1\right)}P_{i,j}\mathcal{L}_{\text{match}}\left(\hat{\bm{y}}_{i},\bm{y}_{j}\right) is independent of NpsubscriptùëÅùëùN_{p} and NgsubscriptùëÅùëîN_{g} in magnitude. We therefore have to guarantee that œµ1‚ÄãH‚Äã(ùë∑1)=œµ2‚ÄãH‚Äã(ùë∑2)subscriptitalic-œµ1Hsubscriptùë∑1subscriptitalic-œµ2Hsubscriptùë∑2\epsilon_{1}\mathrm{H}\left(\bm{P}_{1}\right)=\epsilon_{2}\mathrm{H}\left(\bm{P}_{2}\right). Given an already determined regularization value œµ1subscriptitalic-œµ1\epsilon_{1} for one of the two sizes, the other can be found with œµ2=œµ1‚ÄãH‚Äã(ùë∑1)/H‚Äã(ùë∑2)subscriptitalic-œµ2subscriptitalic-œµ1Hsubscriptùë∑1Hsubscriptùë∑2\epsilon_{2}=\epsilon_{1}\mathrm{H}\left(\bm{P}_{1}\right)/\mathrm{H}\left(\bm{P}_{2}\right). In practice, however, the entropy is not trivial and we can rely on the projection onto the uniform matches

œµ1=œµ2‚Äãlog‚Å°(|spt‚Å°(‚Ñô‚Äã(ùë∑2))|)+1log‚Å°(|spt‚Å°(‚Ñô‚Äã(ùë∑1))|)+1.subscriptitalic-œµ1subscriptitalic-œµ2spt‚Ñôsubscriptùë∑21spt‚Ñôsubscriptùë∑11\epsilon_{1}=\epsilon_{2}\frac{\log\left(\left|\operatorname{spt}\left(\mathbb{P}\left(\bm{P}_{2}\right)\right)\right|\right)+1}{\log\left(\left|\operatorname{spt}\left(\mathbb{P}\left(\bm{P}_{1}\right)\right)\right|\right)+1}. (44)

In the particular case of Proposition¬†1, we can use the approximation |spt‚Å°(‚Ñô‚Äã(ùë∑))|=Npspt‚Ñôùë∑subscriptùëÅùëù\left|\operatorname{spt}\left(\mathbb{P}\left(\bm{P}\right)\right)\right|=N_{p}, which gives

The idea is to determine the optimal value œµ1subscriptitalic-œµ1\epsilon_{1} on toy examples. By setting Np=Np,2subscriptùëÅùëùsubscriptùëÅùëù2N_{p}=N_{p,2}, œµ=œµ2italic-œµsubscriptitalic-œµ2\epsilon=\epsilon_{2} and œµ0=œµ1‚Äã(log‚Å°(Np,1)+1)subscriptitalic-œµ0subscriptitalic-œµ1subscriptùëÅùëù11\epsilon_{0}=\epsilon_{1}\left(\log\left(N_{p,1}\right)+1\right), we can use the simple scaling formula œµ=œµ0/(log‚Å°(Np)+1)italic-œµsubscriptitalic-œµ0subscriptùëÅùëù1\epsilon=\epsilon_{0}/\left(\log\left(N_{p}\right)+1\right). From our experiments, we determined œµ0=0.12subscriptitalic-œµ00.12\epsilon_{0}=0.12.

Appendix E Qualitative Analysis

This section provides qualitative examples (Figure 10 and Figure 11) of some matches, as well as a convergence analysis for DETR and Deformable DETR. We compare the losses and matches ùë∑ùë∑\bm{P} of the two matching algorithms at different training epochs.

Figure¬†10 shows some assignments of the two matching algorithms for DETR on the Color Boxes dataset. We sample examples with few ground truth objects for readability. We only show predictions that are matched at least once with a background ‚àÖ\varnothing ground truth in three consecutive epochs. At the beginning of the training, the Bipartite Matching with the Hungarian algorithm assigns different predictions to the ground truth objects from one epoch to the other. As an example, the algorithm for image ‚Ññ630 assigns predictions {4,49}449\{4,49\}, {8,1}81\{8,1\} and then {99,1}991\{99,1\} to the ground-truth objects {A,B}ùê¥ùêµ\{A,B\} at epoch 25 to 27 (Figure¬†10(a)). The regularized OT match instead provides a smoother solution and is more consistent from one epoch to the other. Later in training, Figure¬†10(a) illustrates that the regularized OT matches are one-to-one and behave like the bipartite ones.

Figure 12 provides the loss curves for DETR on the Color Boxes dataset. The curves suggest that the cross-entropy loss term mainly drives the convergence speedup in the early training epochs. We don‚Äôt observe such speedups on COCO or with Deformable DETR (Figure 13). An explanation could be that the difference between DETR and Deformable DETR is due to the slower convergence of transformers (we also tried DETR with the focal loss from Deformable DETR without improvement). The difference between Color Boxes and COCO is difficult to isolate, but probably due to the wider class diversity in the latter.

Appendix F Number of Sinkhorn Iterations

Using a stopping criterion is not straightforward when solving a batch of matching problems. The scaling algorithm is therefore set to a fixed number of iterations. Figure 14 displays the results for different numbers of iterations. For the balanced OT with 300 predictions (Figure 14(a)), the AP increases only slightly when more than 10 iterations are performed. Furthermore, it is sufficient to run 1 iteration in terms of the AR. For the Unbalanced OT with 8,732 predictions (Figure 14(b)), the metrics are significantly lower when running for less than 5 iterations. Again, running more than 10 iterations only slightly improves the final performance. This fact is supported by Prop.¬†3, which shows that in the limit case where œÑ1=0subscriptùúè10\tau_{1}=0 and œÑ2‚Üí+‚àû‚Üísubscriptùúè2\tau_{2}\rightarrow+\infty, only one or two iterations are required for convergence (depending on the implementation).

Appendix G First Constraint Parameter

In this section, we analyze the effect of the prediction‚Äôs mass constraint parameter œÑ1subscriptùúè1\tau_{1}, while we fix parameter œÑ2subscriptùúè2\tau_{2} to a large value œÑ2=100subscriptùúè2100\tau_{2}=100 to simulate a hard constraint. Parameter œÑ1subscriptùúè1\tau_{1} controls the degree to which variations in the prediction masses are penalized. Each ground-truth object can be matched to the best prediction in the limit case œÑ2‚Üí+‚àû‚Üísubscriptùúè2\tau_{2}\to+\infty and œÑ1=0subscriptùúè10\tau_{1}=0. However, some predictions cannot be matched, and others multiple times. The results for SSD on Color Boxes are displayed in Table 3. Wa can therefore conclude that the first constraint parameter œÑ1subscriptùúè1\tau_{1} has a small influence on the metrics, both with and without NMS. Nevertheless, a higher performance is reached in the balanced case, i.e., when œÑ1‚Üí+‚àû‚Üísubscriptùúè1\tau_{1}\to+\infty.

Appendix H Timing Analysis for SSD

As can be seen in Table¬†4, OT-based matches improve the epoch time (forward pass, compute the match cost, matching algorithm, and backward pass; in blue) for SSD with the Hungarian algorithm by almost 50%. The difference is smaller for DETR and variants as the models are proportionally heavier and the number of predictions smaller.

Appendix I Color Boxes Dataset

This section provides a discussion of the Color Boxes synthetic dataset. It is split into 4,800 training and 960 validation images of 500 √ó\times 400 pixels. Images have a gray background. We uniformly randomly draw between 0 and 30 rectangles of 20 different colors, which define the category of the rectangle. The dimension of the rectangles vary from 12 to 80 pixels and are uniformly randomly rotated. They are placed such that the IoUIoU\mathrm{IoU} between their bounding boxes is at most 0.250.250.25. A gaussian noise of mean 0 and standard deviation 0.05 is added to each pixel value independently. Sample images are drawn in Fig. 15.
